Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Robotic-Assisted and Hand-Rasped Techniques in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized to robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Participants.evidence: the trial included 130 patients eligible for primary cementless THA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized to robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the long-term clinical and radiographic outcomes of robotic-assisted versus hand-rasped femoral component insertion in total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) score, assessed at a minimum follow-up of 10 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomized to robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomized to robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: JOA scores were similar between groups (robotic: 97 ± 5, hand-rasped: 96 ± 7; mean difference 1.4; p = 0.159).
